**G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19**.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 223, § 2**, as the damages alleged fall within the jurisdictional amount of the Brockton District Court.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2**.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 223, § 2**, as the damages alleged fall within the jurisdictional amount of the Brockton District Court.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all individuals and entities owe a duty to act with reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The court expressly states a general principle of Massachusetts tort law that “every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others,” conditioned on foreseeability of the risk. That is effectively the same as the proposition that all individuals and entities owe a duty to act with reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm, and the opinion applies that general duty framework in its analysis of the defendant homeowner’s liability. Thus, the case affirmatively supports the cited proposition, with the usual foreseeability limitation.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all individuals and entities owe a duty to act with reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: Although this is a dissent focused on causation, it explicitly quotes and applies the Massachusetts negligence standard that a defendant must not take risks with respect to a plaintiff’s safety that an ordinarily prudent person would not take, and that liability turns on resulting injury within the foreseeable risk. That articulation presupposes and reaffirms the general duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm, which aligns with the claimed proposition, even though the main dispute in this segment is factual/proximate cause rather than existence of duty.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiffs safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

*Barrett v. Conragan*, 302 Mass. 33 (193.proposition: A duty of reasonable supervision arises where one undertakes the custody and control of children, as in school or recreational contexts.
*Barrett v. Conragan*, 302 Mass. 33 (193.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns liability for a burn suffered during a permanent wave treatment and whether an exculpatory clause is voidable due to fraud. It does not involve children, schools, recreational programs, or any discussion of a duty of reasonable supervision arising from custody or control of children. The case therefore does not support the stated proposition and is unrelated to that doctrine.
*Barrett v. Conragan*, 302 Mass. 33 (193.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff, while receiving a treatment of her hair, described in the record as a “permanent wave,” at the defendant’s place of business, suffered a burn. … The contention is, that before the treatment was given, the plaintiff signed an agreement relieving the defendant from liability in damages for any injuries she might receive during the treatment and that she is thereby barred from recovery in this action. … The question here presented is whether there was evidence to warrant a finding that words or conduct of the defendant’s agent at the time the card was signed constituted fraud…

*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).proposition: A duty of reasonable supervision arises where one undertakes the custody and control of children, as in school or recreational contexts.
*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses when individuals owe a duty of reasonable care, including duties arising from special relationships, and cites Mullins v. Pine Manor College as an example. However, Lyon v. Morphew itself deals with duties of hospital employees toward an independent contractor’s employee on a roof; it does not involve custody or control of children, nor school or recreational supervision. The case neither articulates nor applies a rule about a duty of reasonable supervision arising from custody/control of children, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “A special relationship between the parties may give rise to a common law duty. See Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 198 (1994) (commercial landlord to persons in common areas of rental property); Mullins v. Pine Manor College, supra at 50-51 (college to student); LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., supra at 29 (employer to employee). For example, in Mullins v. Pine Manor College, supra, the college’s vice-president was individually liable for failing to provide adequate security because colleges have a special duty to protect their students.”

*Mullins*, supra; *Brum v. Town of Dartm.raw_text: *Mullins*, supra; *Brum v. Town of Dartmouth*, 428 Mass. 684 (1999)
*Mullins*, supra; *Brum v. Town of Dartm.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff’s son a duty to take reasonable steps to supervise and protect him from foreseeable injuries while in its care.
*Mullins*, supra; *Brum v. Town of Dartm.support_reasoning: The opinion in Brum expressly rejects the existence of a duty by the public defendants to protect the student from third‑party criminal acts while at school, holding that the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act § 10(j) bars such claims and that there is no constitutional duty of protection under § 1983. The court emphasizes that the school’s failure was a nonactionable “failure to prevent” third‑party violence, not a recognized duty to supervise and protect. Thus, the case is authority against, not for, the proposition that the defendant owed the plaintiff’s son a duty to take reasonable steps to supervise and protect him from foreseeable injuries while in its care.
*Mullins*, supra; *Brum v. Town of Dartm.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the principal purpose of § 10 (j) is to preclude liability for failures to prevent or diminish harm, including harm brought about by the wrongful act of a third party. … Accordingly, we conclude that, in Brum v. Dartmouth, § 10 (j) excludes the defendants’ liability for their failure to prevent the killing.”

*Cameron v. Pepin*, 340 Mass. 398 (1960).proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was a direct and proximate cause of the injuries sustained by Plaintiff’s son and the resulting damages.
*Cameron v. Pepin*, 340 Mass. 398 (1960).support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses causation and holds that the plaintiff produced sufficient expert testimony for a jury to find that the defendant’s negligent failure to remove or address the retained root was a probable cause of her ongoing condition and injuries. The court explicitly distinguishes between mere possibility and legal probability, concluding that the evidence showed a probability of causal relation and thus warranted jury consideration on proximate cause.
*Cameron v. Pepin*, 340 Mass. 398 (1960).relevant_excerpt: It remains to consider whether there was sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that there was a causal connection between the negligence of the defendant, if found, and the plaintiff’s injuries. Manifestly, this is a question that a jury could determine only with the aid of expert opinion. … Dr. Nathanson testified that “It is probable that this retained root may have contributed to this… [plaintiff’s] condition” … and that if the “root had been removed within a matter of weeks… the plaintiff probably would not have had any problem.” … We are of opinion that Dr. Nathanson’s testimony, read as a whole, showed a probability of causal relation rather than a mere possibility of such relation.

*Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was a direct and proximate cause of the injuries sustained by Plaintiff’s son and the resulting damages.
*Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).support_reasoning: The court explicitly links Bay State Elevator Company’s negligent maintenance and inspection (disconnected interlocks and frozen governor) to the accident, stating that had these safety devices been functioning, the elevator would have been immobilized or safely stopped and the accident could not have happened. The opinion thus recognizes the defendant’s breach of duty as a direct, proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ injuries and resulting damages, supporting the cited proposition.
*Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).relevant_excerpt: There was expert opinion evidence that the accident happened because one of the contact boxes became unfastened and fell into the pit, lodging in the mechanism and severing the cables. Had the interlock system been operating, the cab would have been immobilized when the contact box fell and the accident could not have happened. Nor could it have occurred had the governor been in working order. ... [T]here was ample evidence, which we need not repeat, of its negligence in inspecting and maintaining the elevator. The plaintiffs ... were unquestionably within the class of persons likely to be injured by its negligence.

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was a direct and proximate cause of the injuries sustained by Plaintiff’s son and the resulting damages.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that plaintiffs failed to establish causation because they offered no evidence explaining why the scaffolding collapsed, and thus could not link any breach of duty by the defendant to the injuries. The court affirms summary judgment precisely because causation was not shown, rather than finding that defendant’s breach was a direct and proximate cause of the injuries. Therefore, the case undercuts, rather than supports, the claimed proposition.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs…bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them… Even if the defendant was remiss in not obtaining a building permit, the plaintiffs have adduced no evidence to support any conclusion…that the accident would have been prevented if the requisite permit had been obtained….”

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B\u20136D**.proposition: Plaintiff and his minor child sustained actual damages as a result of Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and emotional distress compensable under **G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6D**.

*Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp.*, 439.proposition: Plaintiff and his minor child sustained actual damages as a result of Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and emotional distress compensable under **G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6D**.
*Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp.*, 439.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a slip-and-fall negligence claim against a charitable hospital and addresses only the applicability of the charitable damages cap under G.L. c. 231, § 85K and the adequacy of jury instructions. It does not involve claims for a minor child, does not discuss categories of damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or emotional distress in any detail, and does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6D. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about actual damages compensable under those sections.
*Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp.*, 439.relevant_excerpt:
The case was tried before a jury in the Superior Court; they found no liability against the employee and the subcontractors, found Northeast negligent, and awarded Conners damages against Northeast in the amount of $183,000. The trial judge allowed Northeast’s motion to amend the judgment to $20,000, pursuant to G. L. c. 231, § 85K, which limits the liability of charitable corporations to that amount.
...
The sole issue with respect to the hospital is whether it was error for the judge to modify the judgment against it pursuant to G. L. c. 231, § 85K.

*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mt. Builders,.raw_text: *Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mt. Builders, Inc.*, 441 Mass. 131 (2004)
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mt. Builders,.proposition: Plaintiff and his minor child sustained actual damages as a result of Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and emotional distress compensable under **G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6D**.
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mt. Builders,.case_name: Shantigar Foundation v. Bear Mountain Builders
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mt. Builders,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns comparative negligence, allocation of fault among multiple tortfeasors, joint and several liability, and admissibility of sprinkler-system evidence. It involves only property damage to a barn owned by a foundation; there are no personal injuries, no discussion of a plaintiff’s minor child, and no mention or application of G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6D (prejudgment interest and pain-and-suffering/emotional-distress related provisions). Accordingly, it does not establish that a plaintiff and child sustained compensable personal-injury damages under those sections and does not support the proposition cited.
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mt. Builders,.relevant_excerpt: The comparative negligence statute provides, in relevant part: “Contributory negligence shall not bar recovery in any action ... to recover damages for negligence ... if such negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the person or persons against whom recovery is sought, but any damages allowed shall be diminished in proportion to the amount of negligence attributable to the person for whose injury, damage or death recovery is made.” G. L. c. 231, § 85.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, Plaintiff was not comparatively negligent, and any negligence on the part of the Defendant was the primary and proximate cause of injury.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: Award prejudgment and postjudgment interest pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
